title: Ulnar Neuropathy
scope: ** Evaluation and management of ulnar neuropathy from entrapment (cubital tunnel, Guyon canal) and other etiologies in adults. Includes electrodiagnostic workup, conservative management, surgical decision-making, and post-operative care. Covers ED evaluation for acute ulnar injury, inpatient perioperative management, and outpatient chronic management. Excludes brachial plexus injuries and cervical radiculopathy as primary diagnoses (addressed in differential).

Core Labs (Identify Contributing Factors.rationale: Diabetes predisposes to entrapment neuropathy (double crush); identify metabolic contributor
Hypothyroidism predisposes to entrapment neuropathy through connective tissue edema
Renal function (uremic neuropathy); electrolytes; preoperative baseline
Baseline for surgical planning; rule out infection in acute presentations

Extended Labs (Selected Patients).rationale: B12 deficiency as contributor to neuropathy (double crush or concurrent polyneuropathy)
Inflammatory process (rheumatoid arthritis, vasculitis) contributing to nerve compression
Rheumatoid arthritis causing elbow synovitis and ulnar nerve compression
Gout causing olecranon bursitis or tophaceous deposits compressing ulnar nerve

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Multifocal motor neuropathy mimicking ulnar neuropathy; conduction block pattern
If rapidly progressive or multifocal neuropathy with unexplained weight loss

Essential Studies.timing: Standard workup; at least 3-4 weeks after symptom onset for axonal changes to develop
Essential Studies.target: Slowing of ulnar NCV across the elbow (<50 m/s or >10 m/s drop); conduction block at elbow; reduced CMAP amplitude (axonal loss); abnormal sensory NAP; denervation in ulnar-innervated hand intrinsics on EMG

Essential Studies.timing: If trauma suspected; evaluate for fracture, arthritis, cubitus valgus, osteophytes
Essential Studies.target: No fracture; evaluate for cubitus valgus deformity, osteophytes in cubital tunnel, olecranon spur

Extended Studies.item: Ultrasound of ulnar nerve at elbow (CPT 76882)
Extended Studies.timing: Complement to EMG; assess nerve swelling, subluxation, and surrounding pathology
Extended Studies.target: Increased cross-sectional area >10 mm² at cubital tunnel (swollen nerve); ulnar nerve subluxation with elbow flexion; space-occupying lesion

Extended Studies.timing: If mass lesion suspected; preoperative planning; evaluate for ganglion cyst, lipoma, or anomalous muscle
Extended Studies.target: Nerve signal change (T2 hyperintensity indicates edema); space-occupying lesion; anconeus epitrochlearis muscle (anomalous)

Extended Studies.item: MRI wrist (if Guyon canal syndrome suspected)
Extended Studies.timing: Evaluate for mass (ganglion cyst) or hook of hamate fracture compressing ulnar nerve at wrist
Extended Studies.target: Ganglion cyst, lipoma, or hook of hamate fracture in Guyon canal

Extended Studies.timing: If hook of hamate fracture suspected (Guyon canal syndrome); common in racquet sports/cycling
Extended Studies.target: Hook of hamate fracture; carpal bone abnormality

Rare/Specialized.timing: If double crush suspected; C8-T1 radiculopathy in differential
Rare/Specialized.target: No cervical disc herniation or foraminal stenosis at C8-T1

Rare/Specialized.timing: Precise nerve imaging when standard MRI inconclusive; pre-revision surgery
Rare/Specialized.target: Detailed nerve morphology; fascicular pattern; entrapment site localization

Rare/Specialized.timing: Superior bony detail for osteophyte characterization or fracture assessment if MRI contraindicated
Rare/Specialized.target: Bony canal dimensions; osteophytes; heterotopic ossification

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute ulnar neuropathy; post-trauma; prevent flexion during sleep

doseOptions.orderSentence: Elbow splint (extension) Splint at 30-45 degrees of flexion Physical

dosing.instructions: Apply padded elbow splint or towel wrap in 30-45 degrees of flexion; prevents sustained elbow flexion >90 degrees during sleep
dosing.orderSentence: Elbow splint (extension) Splint at 30-45 degrees of flexion Physical

Acute/Emergent.indication: Pain and inflammation at entrapment site

dosing.instructions: Ibuprofen 400-600 mg TID with food; or naproxen 250-500 mg BID; trial 2-4 weeks

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: GI bleeding; renal impairment; aspirin-sensitive asthma

First-Line Conservative Management.indication: All patients with cubital tunnel syndrome; mild-moderate symptoms

doseOptions.orderSentence: Activity modification / nerve gliding exercises Daily Physical

dosing.instructions: Avoid prolonged elbow flexion >90 degrees; avoid leaning on elbow; use telephone headset; position elbow extended during computer use; perform ulnar nerve gliding exercises 3x/day (10 reps each)
dosing.orderSentence: Activity modification / nerve gliding exercises Daily Physical

First-Line Conservative Management.indication: Nocturnal symptoms; paresthesias waking patient; all cubital tunnel patients

doseOptions.orderSentence: Night splinting (elbow extension) 30-45 degrees flexion Physical

dosing.instructions: Padded elbow splint or towel wrap maintaining 30-45 degrees flexion during sleep; use nightly for at least 3 months
dosing.orderSentence: Night splinting (elbow extension) 30-45 degrees flexion Physical

First-Line Conservative Management.indication: Reduce direct pressure on ulnar nerve at elbow; occupational exposure

doseOptions.orderSentence: Elbow pad (cushion over cubital tunnel) Continuous during waking Physical

dosing.instructions: Wear padded elbow sleeve or attach foam pad over medial epicondyle during activities; prevents direct nerve compression
dosing.orderSentence: Elbow pad (cushion over cubital tunnel) Continuous during waking Physical

First-Line Conservative Management.indication: Neuropathic pain; paresthesias; failed activity modification alone

dosing.instructions: Start 100-300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q3-7 days; target 300-600 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day
Start 50-75 mg BID; titrate to 150 mg BID; max 300 mg BID

Surgical Treatment.indication: Cubital tunnel syndrome with stable nerve (no subluxation); mild-moderate compression on EMG; failed 3 months conservative treatment

doseOptions.orderSentence: In situ decompression (simple release) (CPT 64719) Elective Surgical

dosing.instructions: Release of Osborne ligament and fascial constriction at cubital tunnel; preserves nerve in native position; outpatient procedure
dosing.orderSentence: In situ decompression (simple release) (CPT 64719) Elective Surgical

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Ulnar nerve subluxation (relative — may need transposition); medically unfit for surgery
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-op neurologic exam; wound healing; splint for 1-2 weeks; ROM at 2 weeks

Surgical Treatment.indication: Cubital tunnel with nerve subluxation; revision after failed decompression; severe compression with significant axonal loss on EMG

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ulnar nerve transposition (anterior subcutaneous) (CPT 64718) Elective Surgical

dosing.instructions: Anterior transposition of ulnar nerve to subcutaneous position anterior to medial epicondyle; stabilize with fascial sling
dosing.orderSentence: Ulnar nerve transposition (anterior subcutaneous) (CPT 64718) Elective Surgical

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Medically unfit; mild symptoms not warranting surgery
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-op neurologic exam; wound; elbow ROM; splint 2-3 weeks; PT at 3-4 weeks

Surgical Treatment.indication: Revision surgery; ulnar nerve subluxation with thin subcutaneous tissue; high-demand athletes; severe compression

dosing.instructions: Transposition beneath flexor-pronator muscle mass; provides deeper, more protected position; longer recovery than subcutaneous

Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Same; longer immobilization (3-4 weeks); slower return to activity

Surgical Treatment.indication: Alternative to transposition; remove bony prominence causing compression; less tissue disruption than transposition

dosing.instructions: Partial removal of medial epicondyle to relieve compression without nerve mobilization; preserves nerve blood supply

Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-op elbow stability; nerve function; wound

Surgical Treatment.indication: Guyon canal syndrome (ulnar neuropathy at wrist) with identifiable compression (ganglion, hook of hamate fracture); failed conservative treatment

dosing.instructions: Surgical release of Guyon canal; excision of ganglion cyst if present; hook of hamate excision if fractured

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Medically unfit; mild symptoms responding to conservative measures
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-op grip strength; sensory exam; wound healing

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology referral for electrodiagnostic testing (EMG/NCS) to confirm diagnosis, localize lesion, and quantify severity — essential before surgical decision-making
Hand surgery or peripheral nerve surgery referral if moderate-severe ulnar neuropathy on EMG, progressive weakness, or failed 3 months conservative treatment
Occupational therapy for nerve gliding exercises, ergonomic assessment, custom splinting, and workplace modification
Orthopedics if concurrent elbow pathology (arthritis, prior fracture malunion, cubitus valgus) contributing to nerve compression

Patient Instructions.item: Avoid prolonged elbow flexion: do not rest chin on hand, hold phone to ear with affected arm, or sleep with elbows bent tightly — these positions stretch and compress the ulnar nerve
Wear a night splint or wrap a towel around the elbow at bedtime to keep the elbow in a slightly extended position and prevent nocturnal compression
Avoid direct pressure on the inner elbow (funny bone area): do not lean on desks, armrests, or car door; use padded elbow sleeve if unavoidable
Perform nerve gliding exercises 3 times daily as instructed by therapist to maintain nerve mobility and reduce adhesion at the entrapment site
Report worsening hand weakness (dropping objects, difficulty turning keys, or loss of grip strength) — progressive motor loss may require surgical intervention
After surgery, follow splinting and range-of-motion protocols strictly; nerve recovery is slow (1 mm/day or ~1 inch/month) and full recovery may take 6-12 months

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Ergonomic workstation setup: keep elbows at 90 degrees or less when typing; use padded armrests; position keyboard so elbows are not fully flexed
Cyclists: use padded gloves and change hand positions frequently to avoid Guyon canal compression (handlebar palsy)
Manage contributing conditions: optimize diabetes control (HbA1c <7%), treat hypothyroidism, maintain healthy weight to reduce systemic nerve vulnerability
Avoid repetitive elbow flexion/extension activities or sustained gripping if they provoke symptoms; modify occupational tasks with OT guidance
Post-surgical rehabilitation: follow graduated activity protocol; avoid heavy lifting (>10 lbs) for 6 weeks post-transposition; gradual return to full activity by 3 months

differential.features: Neck pain radiating to arm; dermatomal pattern including medial forearm (medial antebrachial cutaneous); weakness in non-ulnar C8-T1 muscles (FPL, APB)
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine; EMG showing C8/T1 denervation in non-ulnar muscles; cervical foraminal stenosis

differential.features: Medial arm/forearm symptoms; positional with overhead activities; vascular symptoms possible; Roos test positive
differential.tests: Chest X-ray (cervical rib); NCS typically normal; MRA/CTA if vascular TOS suspected

differential.features: Numbness in thumb, index, middle fingers (median distribution); Phalen test positive; different distribution than ulnar
differential.tests: EMG/NCS showing median nerve slowing at wrist; normal ulnar studies

differential.features: Lower trunk brachial plexopathy; Horner syndrome; shoulder/arm pain; progressive course; chest imaging abnormal
differential.tests: Chest X-ray or CT chest showing apical mass; MRI brachial plexus

differential.features: Asymmetric distal weakness without sensory loss; conduction block on NCS outside entrapment sites; may mimic ulnar motor neuropathy
differential.tests: NCS showing conduction block in non-entrapment sites; anti-GM1 antibodies; responds to IVIg

differential.features: Progressive weakness without sensory loss; upper and lower motor neuron signs; fasciculations; tongue involvement
differential.tests: EMG showing widespread active denervation; normal sensory NCS; UMN signs on exam

differential.features: Medial elbow pain with gripping/wrist flexion; tenderness at medial epicondyle; no numbness or weakness in ulnar distribution
differential.tests: Clinical exam; normal EMG/NCS; MRI showing epicondylar tendinopathy

differential.features: Thickened, palpable ulnar nerve; skin patches; endemic areas; sensory loss before motor
differential.tests: Skin biopsy (acid-fast bacilli); nerve biopsy; clinical context

differential.features: Trauma history; deformity; acute onset; ulnar nerve stretched or contused during fracture
differential.tests: X-ray elbow showing fracture; clinical history of trauma

evidence.recommendation: EMG/NCS is the gold standard for confirming ulnar neuropathy and localizing the site of entrapment
evidence.source: [AANEM Practice Parameter: electrodiagnosis of ulnar neuropathy at the elbow](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10234589/)

evidence.recommendation: Conservative management with activity modification and night splinting is effective for mild cubital tunnel syndrome
evidence.source: [Svernlov B et al. Scand J Plast Reconstr Surg Hand Surg 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19282413/)

evidence.recommendation: Simple decompression and anterior transposition have similar outcomes for primary cubital tunnel surgery
evidence.source: [Zlowodzki M et al. J Bone Joint Surg Am 2007 (meta-analysis)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18056489/)

evidence.recommendation: Ultrasound cross-sectional area >10 mm² at the elbow is a reliable diagnostic marker for cubital tunnel syndrome
Night splinting reduces nocturnal elbow flexion and improves symptoms in mild cubital tunnel syndrome
evidence.source: [Shah CM et al. J Hand Surg Am 2013](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23455407/)

evidence.recommendation: Nerve recovery after transposition proceeds at ~1 mm/day; complete recovery may take 6-18 months depending on severity
evidence.source: [Mackinnon SE, Novak CB. Clin Orthop Relat Res 1996](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8958578/)

evidence.recommendation: AAOS Clinical Practice Guideline on cubital tunnel syndrome treatment
evidence.source: [Goldfarb CA et al. J Am Acad Orthop Surg 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19810811/)

evidence.recommendation: Surgical treatment is recommended when EMG shows axonal loss or motor weakness is present
evidence.source: [Caliandro P et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27845501/)

monitoring.action: Escalate to surgical referral if progressive decline; EMG reassessment

monitoring.item: Sensory exam (two-point discrimination, Semmes-Weinstein monofilaments — digits 4-5)
monitoring.action: Consider surgery if progressive sensory loss; reassess conservative measures

monitoring.item: Motor exam (interossei, adductor pollicis, FDI — MRC grading)
monitoring.action: Urgent surgical referral if new or worsening weakness <=3/5; repeat EMG

monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months after initial if conservative treatment; 6-12 months post-surgery
monitoring.action: Surgical referral if worsening; consider revision if post-operative worsening
Re-exploration if acute post-operative decline; extended recovery (up to 12 months) expected

disposition.criteria: Stable neurologic exam; no acute motor deficit requiring emergent intervention; splint applied; pain controlled; neurology/hand surgery follow-up within 2-4 weeks
Acute onset after trauma with significant motor deficit; awaiting EMG or surgical consultation
Scheduled surgical decompression/transposition; post-operative monitoring; acute trauma with compartment concern
Rare; only if polytrauma with compartment syndrome or vascular injury affecting upper extremity
EMG/NCS within 2-4 weeks of initial evaluation; repeat EMG at 3-6 months if conservative treatment; post-surgical EMG at 6-12 months
If moderate-severe on EMG: evaluation within 2-4 weeks; post-operative: 2 weeks (wound), 6 weeks (ROM), 3 months, 6 months, 12 months
